question: Question_07
statement:
Determine whether or not the following two matrices are similar:

\[A = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & -1 \\
1 & 3 & 1 \\
-1 & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix} \text{ and }
B = \begin{bmatrix}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 1 \\
0 & 0 & 2
\end{bmatrix}\]
sols:
We are going to work under the assumption that the two matrices are
similar and use properties of similar matrices to aid us in solving this
question.

For two matrices to be similar $A$ and $B$ must satisfy the equation
$A = P^{-1}BP$

The main properties of similar matrices which we will use to verify this
equation is that:

1) Similar matrices have the same eigenvalues 2) Similar matrices have
the same Jordan canonical form

So, we need to get the two matrices into Jordan form and compare them.

The Jordan canonical form is given by $B = GJG^{-1}$

Where $G$ is just the matrix of eigenvectors.

We$^{\prime}$re going to start with $B$ as it$^{\prime}$s easy to pick
out the eigenvalues from the diagonal, which must also be the
eigenvalues of $A$ from our known properties.

Eigenvalues\[\lambda = 1, 2, 2\]

So let$^{\prime}$s get our eigenvectors!

You should know how to get eigenvectors from eigenvalues (solve
$Bx = \lambda x$)

The eigenvectors of $B$ are:

$v_{1} = \begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
1\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix} v_{2} = \begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
1\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix} v_{3} = \begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix}$

And so $G = \begin{bmatrix}
0 &0 &1 \\ 
1 & 1& 0\\ 
0 & 1& 0
\end{bmatrix}$

Besides knowing the formula for obtaining the inverse of a $3$x$3$
matrix, one can also obtain it by $^{\prime}$rref$^{\prime}$-ing the
augmented matrix:

$\begin{bmatrix}
B
\left.\begin{matrix}
\end{matrix}\right|
I
\end{bmatrix}$

However you want to do it, we obtain:

$G^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}
0&1 &-1 \\ 
0&0 &1 \\ 
1 & 0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}$

Using this information we find that our J, the form we want to get, is:

$J = \begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &0 \\ 
0&2 & 0\\ 
0&0 &2 
\end{bmatrix}$

Now we just do the same steps again for $A$ and then we$^{\prime}$re
done!

So, $A = HJH^{-1}$, and we already know our eigenvalues as they are just
the same as B!

The eigenvectors of $A$ are:

$u_{1} = \begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-1\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix} u_{2} = \begin{bmatrix}
-1\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix} u_{3} = \begin{bmatrix}
-1\\ 
1\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix}$

And so $H = \begin{bmatrix}
1 &-1 & -1\\ 
-1 & 0& 1\\ 
1& 1& 0
\end{bmatrix}$ and with $H$ we obtain $H^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix}
1 &1 &1 \\ 
-1&-1 &0 \\ 
1& 2 &1 
\end{bmatrix}$

With these two matrices known we can see that:

$J = \begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 &0 \\ 
0&2 & 0\\ 
0&0 &2 
\end{bmatrix}$

And so the two matrices have the same Jordan canonical form, and are
thus similar because of the following:

With us knowing that the two matrices have the same Jordan form we can
show what $P$ and $P^{-1}$ will be:

if $B = GJG^{-1}$ and $A = HJH^{-1}$ then

$J = G^{-1}BG$ substituting that into our other equation gets:

$A = HG^{-1}BGH^{-1}$

So just let $P^{-1} = HG^{-1}$ and $P = GH^{-1}$

and we get $A = P^{-1}BP$ which is what we sought out to begin with!
